name: Cook Islands
description: The Cook Islands, also known as the Southern Cook Islands or Rarotonga Islands, are an island country in the South Pacific Ocean. Comprising 15 small islands, of which 14 are coral atolls and one is a raised volcanic island, they are renowned for their stunning turquoise lagoons, pristine beaches, and vibrant Polynesian culture. The islands offer a unique blend of relaxation, adventure, and cultural immersion, attracting visitors seeking an escape to paradise.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: Aitutaki is the most populous island and the administrative center of the Cook Islands.
quickFacts.detail: While Rarotonga is the most visited, Aitutaki boasts the largest lagoon and is a vital hub for the islands' economy.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: The Cook Islands have a small but resilient population, primarily of Polynesian descent.
quickFacts.detail: The population is spread across the islands, with a significant portion residing on Rarotonga.

quickFacts.label: Official Language
quickFacts.description: Cook Islands Māori is the indigenous language and remains an integral part of daily life.
quickFacts.detail: English is also widely spoken, particularly in government and tourism sectors.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The CDT is pegged to the New Zealand Dollar at a 1:1 ratio.
quickFacts.detail: New Zealand Dollars are also widely accepted.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: The economy is largely reliant on tourism and remittances.
quickFacts.detail: Agriculture and fishing contribute significantly, but are limited in scale.

climateData.title: Tropical Climate
climateData.description: The Cook Islands enjoy a tropical climate characterized by consistently warm temperatures and high humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is distributed relatively evenly, with distinct wet and dry seasons.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Summer (November - April)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Summer brings consistently high temperatures, averaging around 28°C (82°F), and increased rainfall. This is the peak tourist season.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Autumn (May - September)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Autumn offers a pleasant balance of warm temperatures and reduced rainfall. The humidity is lower, and the seas are calmer.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Winter (June - October)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Winter is the coolest and driest season, with average temperatures around 24°C (75°F). It's a popular time for visitors seeking a respite from the heat.

naturalWonders.name: Rarotonga Lagoon
naturalWonders.description: The Rarotonga Lagoon is a breathtaking expanse of turquoise water, surrounded by a ring of lush volcanic mountains. It’s a haven for marine life and a focal point of the islands’ tourism industry.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The lagoon’s unique shape and clarity are due to the volcanic reef that encircles it. It’s a protected marine area, teeming with colorful coral and diverse fish species.
viewingTips: Snorkel or dive in the coral gardens
Enjoy a sunset cocktail on the beach

naturalWonders.name: Aitutaki Island
naturalWonders.description: Aitutaki is renowned for its stunning lagoon, often described as the ‘South Pacific’s most beautiful lagoon’. It’s a true paradise with pristine beaches and a relaxed atmosphere.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The island’s centerpiece is One Foot Island (Motu Nui), a small islet with a white-sand beach and a palm-fringed lagoon. It’s a popular spot for romantic getaways and idyllic escapes.
viewingTips: Take a lagoon tour to explore the motus
Enjoy a picnic on One Foot Island
Watch the sunset over the lagoon

ecosystemData.title: Coral Reef Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: The Cook Islands’ coral reefs are a vital part of the marine environment, providing habitat for a diverse range of species and protecting the coastline from erosion. These ecosystems are under increasing pressure from climate change and human activities.

biodiversityCategories.name: Coral Reef Fish
biodiversityCategories.description: The Cook Islands boast a rich diversity of coral reef fish, including colorful reef fish, groupers, snappers, and parrotfish.

statistics.details: Diverse species adapted to the lagoon environment
Significant biomass supporting the food chain

biodiversityCategories.name: Mangrove Ecosystems
biodiversityCategories.description: Mangrove forests fringe the coastlines of many islands, providing crucial nursery grounds for marine life and protecting against storm surges.

activities.title: Island Adventures
activities.description: The Cook Islands offer a wide range of activities for visitors of all interests, from relaxing on pristine beaches to exploring lush rainforests and diving in vibrant coral reefs.

activityCategories.name: Hiking
activityCategories.description: Explore the islands’ volcanic landscapes and rainforests on a variety of hiking trails.

activities.name: Rarotonga Trail
activities.description: A scenic trail circling Rarotonga, offering stunning views of the lagoon and coastline.

activities.name: Mount Rotuman Trail
activities.description: A challenging hike to the summit of Mount Rotuman, the highest point in the Cook Islands.
activities.requirements: Sturdy hiking boots, plenty of water, rain gear

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
activityCategories.description: Enjoy a variety of water sports in the crystal-clear waters of the Cook Islands’ lagoon.

activities.name: Snorkeling
activities.description: Explore the vibrant coral reefs and diverse marine life.

activities.name: Diving
activities.description: Discover the underwater wonders of the Cook Islands’ coral reefs.

equipment.hiking: Sturdy hiking boots, backpack, water bottle

safety: Be aware of the sun's intensity
